ngoList.address: Artscapes SCO 7 II Floor Sector 30 D
ngoList.title: Artscapes
ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Three years back it all started with a thought, a thought for art. It all began with a dream, a dream to promote art. Today, it is a reality, a reality that grows each day in the form of Artscapes, a non profit, non government organization, which promotes, supports and provides a platform to foster excellence in various dimensions of art. Artscapes aims to bridge the void that exists between artists and art lovers by providing a range of shows, events, seminars, camps and workshops. Our hugely successful ventures include Art Exhibition organized at Punjab Arts Council, Chandigarh in January, 2011. The exhibition was inaugurated by Justice MMS Bedi, Punjab & Haryana High Court. An Indo Canadian Art Exhibition Confluence was organised in November 2011. It successfully brought together 43 artists from across the country and Canada. Chief guest Justice Ajay Tewari inaugurated the event, which had Scot Slessor, Consul General of Canada, as the guest of honour. Artscapes held a Jugalbandi Fusion Nite with Salil Bhatt and an exhibition at Park Plaza in Chandigarh in June 2012. An art event, Freedom of Expression, was organised by Artscapes to mark Canadas 145th birthday on July 1, 2012. Several young and senior artists from Chandigarh came together to paint a massive live canvas expressing their ideas extempore. Many well known people, including Justice MMS Bedi, Baltej Dhillon, the first turbaned Sikh to be admitted to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, Manohar Lal, Principal, Govt. College of Art, Chandigarh, Jodh Singh et al took part in the exhibition. In March 2012, we held the first All India Women Artists Exhibition 2012. The exhibition was a confluence of women artists from all over the country. This unique, first of its kind, exhibition in the region was a source of inspiration for all aspiring women artists and provided them a platform to showcase their creations. 820 works of art were received out of which 146 were scrutinized. The responsibility of judging the best works was entrusted to veteran artist Shobha Broota who went into each minute detail and rewarded the best among the best. Winning artists were given cash awards amounting Rs 1.26 Lac. Certificates of merit were also presented. In association with Times Group and Chandigarh Police, Artscapes hosted the IGP Invitational Golf tournament, one of the biggest events in North India. It was a perfect blend of golf and glitz. The inaugural tournament was held in March 2012 at the Chandigarh Golf Club with a number of celebrities, including Sunny Deol, Abhay Deol, Sanjay Dutt, Kirron Kher, Mark Boyle, Kathryn Olympian Milkha Singh, Jeev Milkha, Arjuna awardee Harmeet Kahlon and Golfer Gurbaaz Mann, taking part. As part of our endeavours, Artscapes, launched Ludhiana Art Beat in November 2012 to identify, recognise and promote talented artists in Ludhiana. Short listed finalists got a chance to exhibit their work and a live workshop was conducted by eminent artist Kalicharan Gupta followed by a lecture.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: In order to propagate Social Health Activities the Association through its District Branches, holds Seminars, Declamation, Lectures, Debates, etc., generally on the topics mentioned below: Empowerment of Women, Evils of dowry, Drug addiction, Importance of Family Planning, Need for Happy Family life, Marital discord, broken homes, Awareness about Aids and its prevention, Immunization, Rights of women, Prevention of Female feticide etc. On International Womens Day (March 8th, 2016) a Free Medical Camp was organized for Dental, Eyes, Skin and Medical ailments etc. and free medicines were also provided. The Medical Camp organized in association with Rotary Club Chandigarh Central at Nari Niketan Building, Sector 55, SAS Nagar (Mohali). International Womens Day was also celebrated by all the district branches of ASHI, and a large number of women and girls participate in the functions. We propose to run Training Centers for Computers, Beautician Course, Stitching Embroidery, Call Center, etc. The District Branches of the Association take keen interest in cases of Marital discord, Behaviour problems, Dowry disputes. District Branches hold seminars for creating general awareness among women and girls against social evils and urge them to fight against social aggression etc. SHORT STAY HOMES: The ASHI Punjab State Branch, Chandigarh has been successful in getting three Short Stay Homes sanctioned from the Govt. of India for helping the destitute women and girls in the State as mentioned below: Sanjeevni at Jalandhar, Savera at Chandigarh, Sahara at Amritsar. At the Short Stay Homes for women in discord and disorganization, emotionally disturbed, unmarried mothers, women of weaker sections requiring shelter and protection etc., are provided accommodation for short stay in these Homes. Here they are provided free Board and Lodging, rehabilitation and medical treatment, protection and help to build future for them through academic, well equipped vocational training, so that they can become economically independent. They are provided facilities of games as well. The inmates are imparted training in various handicrafts such as making leather goods, purses, Dak Pads, Warrian Pappar, Surf etc. and after trained perfectly they are helped find a livelihood. The Association takes special interest in getting them married to suitable persons to enable them to lead honourable life. Grant in aid to run these Homes is given by the Govt. of India, Ministry of Human Resources Development, New Delhi.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The main focus of CEVAâ€™s work is to initiate and carry out dialogues within the community for mutual education, communication and empowerment. Education and re-education: All our activities are aimed at education and re-education within society and within different groups in society (like women, children and young people, senior citizens, disadvantaged and marginalised communities), through the use of formal and non-formal media like Community Theatre, Environmental Theatre, Street Performances and Fairs and films, interventions in schools and training/learning programs. Our preferred mode for facilitating education is through dialogue and multi-lateral communication. Our activities are focused on creating/opening up different spaces for learning and for generating conversations and dialogue. These are - workshops or learn-shops as we have come to call them, for different kinds of learning exchanges; Learning melas (Fairs) in streets and public spaces where we conduct open learning exchanges for the community; community theatre; public meetings; and setting up different kinds of discussion forums. Friends of Children Corners: Under a project funded by the Ministry of Women and Child Welfare, GOI, New Delhi, we organise Learning Melas, in the city. â€œFriends of Children Cornerâ€ as we call the mela, has been conceptualised as a â€˜learning spaceâ€™, created in residential areas, markets and public spaces, melas, community festivals, school functions and get-togethers. It is a free, non-competitive space where adults and children can come and play and learn together. It is a congenial â€˜learning environmentâ€™ with an emphasis on learning through fun and games. CEVAâ€™s School Support Program: Objectives: 1. To work in tandem with schools to help implement new ideas and teaching strategies in order to facilitate academic progress and development of higher order thinking skills in students. 2. To work within schools to build on the strengths of the school and of the students and to facilitate change in areas that need improvement. 3. To undertake programs to train teachers in the skills necessary for activity based teaching and the teaching of higher order thinking skills. 4. To work within schools to help build capabilities and systems necessary for this purpose. Teacher Training: Although our work in schools involves mentoring teachers in their classrooms, we are also working with the Rayat and Bahra College of Education, Punjab. DRAMA REPERTORY - Community Theatre Play Productions. We create and perform community plays in the form of street plays, theatreâ€“in-the-round and interactive performances for the community. (i.e. in community spaces, halls and courtyards) Class-room Theatre We have done science/math theatre in class-rooms as part of the exercise of â€˜trying outâ€™ activities to be included in an â€˜Activity Bankâ€™. Story-telling: Telling stories with props, story-boards, doing story-boards and improvisations are a part of our melas, workshops and performances. Looking for the math and science in stories, creating stories to understand phenomenon has been a part of the effort.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The crux of CTWâ€™s work lies in the facilitation of dialogue within the community thru Community Theatre. The search has been for alternatives to the traditional frontal methods of communication in theatre as well as out side of it. For this purpose we have used community theater, films, the audio-visual, organized activities in community and public spaces, and used other formal and non-formal communication media to reach out to people. Theatre in Chandigarh has obviously come of age. It started as a genteel social activity and remained for long confined to schools, colleges and clubs. The pillars of society patronized it as some sort of a pretence for their `culturednessâ€™. Through its own inner impulses, however, it evolved into a variety of forms both academic and experimental. Theatre activity remained by and large a transplanted species which refused for all the efforts and labour to get acclimatized to the environment of the synthetic city of babus and bearers, bureaucrats and liaison agents and of forbidding and cold architectural designs and cleverly segregated and dissocialized habitation. In the background of the insipid philistinism which is the hallmark of social life of Chandigarh the arrival of Community Theatre Workshop (CTW) was some sort of a happening both theatrical and social. The whole idea of a theatre which has â€œno time for poetry or ornate expressionâ€, and no use of curtain sets, props, lighting or even seating arrangements was shocking. CTW believes only in the human material to crystallize the vision of â€œpure theatreâ€ in which the action itself emerges as the real fact both as an image of the reality and a symbol of its under lying meaning of lack of it, our main endeavor is to break through the four walls of conventional theatre and bring the performance directly into the streets right amidst the common folk. Through this be aspire for establishing an â€œorganic bond between the performers and the audienceâ€ so that both could join into the awaken into the social relevance of entertainment. Community Theatre Community Theatre takes theatre to a much broader plane. It is very different from the formalised theatre that we are used to seeing in the theatre halls. The accent is on free expression. We believe that every person has infinite potential and possibilities as well as a reservoir of experience within themselves. This potential and experience is a valuable learning resource. The processes of community theatre create spaces and opportunities for participants to articulate their perceptions and experience freely. Theatre activity becomes a psychological space for participants to renew and revise their self-image and to re-define for themselves, their existing roles.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Conservation Himalayas has had a long-term perspective in its vision and goals. The human dimension of the human-wildlife conflict issues is our priority with the focus on the sustainable livelihood improvement of the stakeholder communities in the forest fringe villages. Three community livelihood improvement training centers have been set up in Uttarakhand as a strategy to reduce forest dependency activities of the women and connecting them with income generating skill development skills.

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: Department of Interior USFWS Washington DC
sourceOfFunds.purpose: The USFWS awarded grant to the Conservation Himalayas wa used for the following purposes: 1. Mapping of the Human Elephant-Conflict (HEC) sensitive areas in Hardwar Forest Division 2. Construction of a CLI Training Center at Gaindikhata in Hardwar 3. Distribution of the LPG cooking gas among the HEC-affected fringe families at Gaindikhata 4. HEC mitigation conservation education for the stakeholder communities 5. Distribution of Sewing machines to the HEC-affected women in the CLI center

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Don Bosco is an international organisation of repute that has been functioning in the city through its head office at Navjeevan Church at sector 24, Chandigarh. Don Bosco has just celebrated its 150 years of foundation on the 18th of December 2009. Besides providing Educational and Vocational training the Chandigarh office focuses on the key areas of Adult Education, Drug De â€“ Addiction, Self Help Groups (SHG) and Balwadis, Awareness cum Medical Camps, counselling centre, Life Skill Programmes,Community development Programmes, Education Programmes for Class X, XII, BA- Graduation,HIV-AIDS Target Intervention Programmes in Amritsar (Punjab) etc. Don Bosco Centre offers life skills and personality development programmes for youngsters, especially from the slums / colonies. Basic and advanced computer literacy programmes twinned with spoken English classes. Non-formal vocational training is offered in cosmetology, cutting and stitching and through self- help projects etc During their work in the slum colonies of Chandigarh, the staff of Don Bosco came across a number of children and adults with Special Needs. Don Bosco Sawera was formed that provides educational, vocational, community based services for children with special needs.
